title: A Bullying President at an Ugly Debate
summary: Biden didn't distinguish himself either, but Trump came out of it looking like even more of a loser.. Where does all this stand, days after the debate and a month before the election? All summer, wise people were saying Joe Biden's ahead but Donald Trump's in the game, can't write him off, a lot of issues (rising crime, economic fear, a poor Democratic convention) are going in his favor, this thing is dynamic.

title: Boeing to Consolidate 787 Dreamliner Production in South Carolina
summary: Plane maker's move to combine final assembly in North Charleston plant follows sharp decline in demand for wide-body jets amid pandemic. Boeing Co. said it is ending production of its 787 Dreamliner in the Seattle area after more than a decade and plans to consolidate assembly of the popular wide-body jet to its factory in South Carolina next year.

title: Trump Campaign Opposes Changing Debate Rules
summary: The nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates hopes to announce changes in the next two days after Tuesday's chaotic spectacle. WASHINGTON-President Trump's campaign is calling on debate organizers not to change the rules for the next two face-offs with Democratic nominee Joe Biden, but said Mr. Trump has no plans to skip the events.

title: What's the Ballot Deadline? Who Knows
summary: A month before Nov. 3, the election's rules are being set by lawsuit.. Barely a month is left before Election Day, yet voting rules in pivotal states are still being litigated. This week Pennsylvania Republicans asked the U.S. Supreme Court to halt a state judicial ruling that says late ballots must be counted, even if they lack postmarks and arrive three days after the statutory deadline.

title: Hope for California's Schools
summary: Gavin Newsom vetoes a K-12 curriculum in Marxist indoctrination.. Since California became a one-party state, a major responsibility of the Governor has been to protect its citizens from extremist legislation that sails through the Democratic-supermajority Legislature. Former Gov. Jerry Brown sometimes played that role, and Gov. Gavin Newsom did the same Wednesday by vetoing an anti-American K-12 curriculum mandate.

title: George Melloan
summary: A storied Journal editor who reshaped U.S. political debate.. 'Back to you with a little smoothing. rgds, geo." For two generations of Wall Street Journal editorial writers around the world, that was the typical note from George Melloan atop the edited version of an editorial. George might have rewritten half of your draft, but he always made the medicine go down with that note about "smoothing."

title: 'I Am the Democratic Party'
summary: Joe Biden says he's the boss but ducks on Supreme Court-packing and the Senate filibuster.. So declared Joe Biden at Tuesday night's debate as he tried to parry President Trump's charge that he will be a false front man for the Democratic Party's increasingly dominant left. But for a man who says he's in charge, the former Vice President sure is reluctant to say what he believes in.

title: No Escape From Hong Kong
summary: The 12 boat people who tried to flee to Taiwan are still in jail in China.. The hallmark of a truly oppressive regime is that it won't let its people leave. Think the Berlin Wall, the Soviet Union or Cuba. Now that's becoming the fate of Hong Kong's formerly free people.

title: A George Melloan Sampler: A Global View Across the Decades
summary: He joined this newspaper in 1952 and left a wealth of wisdom behind.. Former Journal deputy editorial-page editor George Melloan died this week at 92. He joined the Journal as a reporter in 1952, retired in 2006 and continued contributing occasionally, most recently in June. These are excerpts of his work.

title: Farmers Will Reap the Benefits of Modi's Reforms
summary: India's agriculture industry needs deregulation badly. Eventually, it'll have to shrink.. Can agriculture in India be fixed? No other question directly affects so many people in Asia's third-largest economy. An estimated 263 million Indians-55% of the country's workforce-eke out a living from farms. This makes any attempt at agriculture reform both economically significant and politically risky.

title: Beat Covid Without a Vaccine
summary: Home testing and 'digital passports' could stop outbreaks.. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says it'll be mid-2021 before a Covid-19 vaccine is available in quantities sufficient to "get back to our regular life." Does that mean nine more months of lockdown? Not necessarily. There's an alternative: repeated, frequent, rapid at-home testing. At least one such test, Abbott Labs ' BinaxNOW, is already being produced for the government. Others are in development.

title: The Coronavirus College Scam
summary: My son's university invited him back to campus for remote classes at $70,000 a year. He got a job instead.. My 20-year-old son attends Villanova University. It is a fine school, but this year it costs $70,000 a year for room, board and tuition-for online classes. This fall most colleges are charging full tuition to families like mine to have kids on campus without real classrooms. This is like going to a restaurant and never getting served, but still getting handed the bill.

title: The James Comey Election
summary: His testimony this week was a reminder of everything that enrages Trump voters.. The political elite remain puzzled-and in agony-over how Donald Trump could still be in the race. A bullying debater! A purveyor of mistruths! A would-be autocrat! How has our country come to this?

title: 'Agent Sonya' Review: Lover, Mother, Soviet Spy
summary: A committed communist, 'Sonya' embarked on a long career in espionage-at one point serving as a courier for Klaus Fuchs-and never got caught.. Though little known to the broader world, Ursula Kuczynski, born in 1907 into a wealthy, cultured Jewish family in Berlin, was one of the most successful spies of the 20th century. She worked for the GRU-Soviet Military Intelligence-in China, Eastern Europe, Switzerland and, most damagingly, Britain. Beginning in the early 1930s as the provider of a safe house for spies to meet, she was soon trained as a radio operator, courier and liaison between communist underground activists and Moscow. Eventually she ran her own network of Soviet spies in Nazi Germany and, after war broke out, in Britain. There she served as a courier for Klaus Fuchs, the émigré physicist who later worked at Los Alamos and betrayed its secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: Telehealth Startup Hims Strikes Deal to Go Public Through SPAC
summary: Company to list on New York Stock Exchange and raise additional capital. Telehealth startup Hims Inc. said it plans to go public by merging with a blank-check company in a deal that will value the combined business at about $1.6 billion.

title: New York City Officials Work to Combat Distrust in Coronavirus Hot Spot
summary: Apathy and misinformation are widespread in Brooklyn's Gravesend, where the average Covid-19 positivity rate is 6.9%.

title: High Court Nominee Coney Barrett Signed Antiabortion Ad in 2006
summary: Two-page ad in an Indiana newspaper brings fresh attention to a key issue in her confirmation battle. WASHINGTON-Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett signed an antiabortion newspaper advertisement more than a decade ago that blasted the high court's landmark abortion rights ruling in Roe v. Wade, a public stance that brought new focus Thursday to a central issue in her confirmation battle.

title: Nation's Largest School District Opens for All Grade Levels
summary: About three dozen classrooms, one program for special-needs students are temporarily shut down. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio cheered on the final group of public schools to reopen Thursday, even as he said a Queens program for disabled children became the first to shut for two weeks because of cases of the new coronavirus.

title: You Call This Bread? Subway's Is Too Sugary to Count, Irish Court Finds
summary: Irish court finds bread at Subway sandwich shops doesn't meet the legal definition; Subway replies, it 'is, of course, bread'. Ireland's top court says it knows what bread is, and the stuff Subway uses for its sandwiches isn't it.

title: Pandemic Pain Persists for Big Oil Companies
summary: A tepid rebound in fossil fuel demand and longer-term concerns about renewable energy and electric vehicles are driving down company values. Major oil companies signaled they remain under extreme financial pressure and oil prices slid Thursday as demand for fossil fuels rebounds slowly after being crushed by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Travel Services Provider Fined $5.9 Million for Cuba Sanctions Violations
summary: Generali Global Assistance rerouted payments to avoid reimbursing Cuba-based entities directly, a U.S. sanctions watchdog said. Generali Global Assistance Inc. agreed to pay nearly $5.9 million to resolve apparent violations of U.S. sanctions on Cuba, in a settlement that the U.S. Treasury Department said underscored the need for companies to be cognizant of indirect sanctions risks.

title: 'On the Rocks': Father-Daughter Detective Dance
summary: Bill Murray and Rashida Jones confront the mysteries of marriage across two generations in Sofia Coppola's latest.. A director of distinction, Danny Boyle, once told me he always tried to follow the advice of the peerless David Lean and declare his ambitions for a film during its first five minutes. Another director of distinction, Sofia Coppola, declares hers deftly in the first nine seconds of "On the Rocks," which is playing in select theaters and will stream via Apple TV+ on Oct. 23rd. Over a black screen Bill Murray says in measured tones: "And remember, don't give your heart to any boy. You're mine until you get married. Then you're still mine."

title: 'First Ladies' Review: Women of the White House
summary: A CNN documentary series offers detailed, dramatic accounts of six presidential wives, among them Jackie Kennedy and Eleanor Roosevelt.. The astonishingly detailed portraits in "First Ladies" (begins Sunday, 10 p.m., CNN) are distinguished in their scholarship, mesmerizing in their drama. The series, which traces the lives and works of six presidents' wives, begins with Michelle Obama and continues in subsequent weeks with Jackie Kennedy, Nancy Reagan, Eleanor Roosevelt, Lady Bird Johnson and Hillary Clinton.

title: 'Supremacist': A Proxy for Racism Since Its Early Days
summary: Donald Trump's handling of the topic in Tuesday's presidential debate has refocused attention on the term and the groups it describes. After the first presidential debate on Tuesday, Merriam-Webster reported that the top lookup in its online dictionary was the phrase "white supremacist." Searches were up by 40 times the recent daily average.

title: 'Macbeth' Review: Shocking Shakespeare
summary: Patrick Stewart stars in Rupert Goold's blood-soaked rendition of the tragedy, streaming on PBS, which transplants the action to an unnamed Soviet-bloc state.. Shakespeare's plays rarely come to Broadway, and when they do, it tends to be in the form of star-driven productions imported from England. Of these, the one that has lodged itself most firmly in my memory is Rupert Goold's blood-soaked 2007 Chichester Theatre Festival staging of "Macbeth," which later played in London's West End and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, transferring from there to Broadway's Lyceum Theatre for a universally acclaimed eight-week run. Granted, its box-office success was due in substantial part to the presence in the cast of a TV star, Patrick Stewart. On the other hand, Mr. Stewart is also a stage actor of distinction, and Mr. Goold's high-concept modern-dress production, which transplanted the action from 11th-century Scotland to an unnamed Soviet-bloc state, served the play exceptionally well.

title: Tig Notaro and Sarah Cooper on What Comedy Is Mainstream Now
summary: The comedians talked comedy amid coronavirus at the Journal's Women in the Workplace Forum. Sarah Cooper started 2020 going to open mic nights in the hope of making a name for herself on the stand-up circuit. Fast-forward nine months, and she is an internationally-acclaimed comedian with over 2 million Twitter followers and a Netflix special due later in the fall.

title: 'Flesh and Blood' Review: Loves, Illicit and Lost
summary: A PBS series combines a mystery, an intrusive neighbor and an enthralling family drama.. The opening scene of "Flesh and Blood"-flashing police lights, a bloody rock indicating that something terrible has happened to someone-provides a sense of certainty that's otherwise rare in this enthralling drama awash in ambivalence. In the midst of the excitement comes the voice-over of the character who will be the most potent source of mystery in these four delectable hours. She's Mary, the intrusive neighbor-cheerful, generous, a woman forever delivering little gifts. And one, also, who keeps an unfailingly watchful eye on the family next door, the central figures in this tale. We've seen this character before, a cliché of sorts, but as portrayed by Imelda Staunton this Mary is unforgettable-utterly convincing in her concern for the friends next door she's known for 40 years.

title: New U.S. Coronavirus Cases Rise Slightly
summary: With Covid-19 accelerating in 34 states, cases countrywide since the pandemic began now exceed 7.2 million. New coronavirus cases in the U.S. edged up slightly, as more than 42,000 infections were reported Wednesday, while some states sought to control a surge in cases and others progressed with reopening plans.

title: 'Dick Johnson Is Dead' Review: A Lively Way to Die
summary: Kirsten Johnson's hybrid documentary serves to help her spirited father cope with his fear of death.. One of the hits of early TV, a documentary series called "This Is Your Life," surprised guests by taking them through elaborately researched retrospectives of their lives. Kirsten Johnson ("Cameraperson") takes another approach in a remarkable Netflix film that could be titled "This Is Your Death" and is actually called "Dick Johnson Is Dead."

title: As Many as Half of New York City Restaurants Could Close Due to Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Situation could worsen if virus levels spike, forcing the state to reconsider allowing them to serve. As many as half of New York City's nearly 24,000 restaurants and bars could be forced to close permanently because of coronavirus restrictions imposed to date, according to the state.

title: Treasury Warns Against Keeping Ransomware Payments Quiet
summary: Officials urge victims and companies that help them to be wary of payments to blacklisted entities in places such as Russia and North Korea. Victims of ransomware schemes and financial institutions could violate sanctions or anti-money-laundering rules-and face stiff penalties-if they facilitate or make payments to attackers, the U.S. Treasury Department said in a pair of advisories Thursday.

title: Are Lincoln, Douglas Laughing or Weeping?
summary: What a demonstration from two people vying to hold the most powerful position in the world. It was like two kids duking it out behind the half-moon shed.. Definitely not your Lincoln-Douglas debate ("Trump, Biden Trade Insults in Debate Full of Crosstalk," Page One, Sept. 30). What a demonstration from two people vying to hold the most powerful position in the world. It was like two kids duking it out behind the half-moon shed. Where was the debate? What happened to respecting the rights of the debaters? What happened to respecting the moderator? If this is the template for future debates, please cancel them now. Don't humiliate the office of the president of the U.S. any more than these two have already.

title: How Much Vaccine and Testing Is Sufficient?
summary: Just tell me the probabilities and the confidence intervals, and let me take my own chances.. Drs. Scott Gottlieb and Mark McClellan make the unexceptionable point that "clinical trials must continue until they establish whether the vaccines cause a substantial reduction in the likelihood and severity of Covid infections without safety problems" ("Trump Can Take Credit for Vaccine Progress but Shouldn't Rush It," op-ed, Sept. 28). But if I am 99.99% sure that a vaccine is safe, I don't have to have certainty that it is effective. Getting vaccinated would even have something to recommend it were the vaccine only 50% likely to be effective, if it were 99.99% certain to be safe.

title: Good Riddance to the Unsanitary Handshake
summary: Better education has shown handshaking to be an unsanitary practice which should have been discouraged many pandemics ago.. Regarding W. Taylor Reveley's "Trump, Biden and the Untimely Death of the Handshake" (op-ed, Sept. 26): The concept of civility in the West has been canceled on American college campuses for years. Students in many universities have been taught that civility is a tool to reinforce white patriarchy and therefore part of America's systemic-racism problem, not part of the solution. Civility allegedly patronizes people of color and is used to deflect expression of legitimate grievances. If you shake hands with a privileged person, it merely signals egalitarian virtue that doesn't exist in a racist American society. Mr. Reveley contends that the handshake "reinforces the equality of citizens" in our democracy. Exactly right, but therein lies the rub-many in America believe that there never has been true equality of citizens here, so reinforcing the myth with a handshake is detrimental. Covid-19 and warring politicians hastened the demise of the handshake, but it already was headed toward oblivion because of the culture wars.

title: The Supreme Court Should Resist All Efforts to Pack It
summary: A court that can be reconstituted every time the executive and legislative bodies change hands isn't independent.. Regarding your editorial "Breaking Judicial Norms: A History" (Sept. 21): It's hard to imagine anything more corrupting of an independent judiciary than packing the Supreme Court for partisan purposes. But it's an open question whether the Supreme Court would uphold a packing scheme. All constitutional powers have limits, and there's a compelling argument for the Court to find court packing an unconstitutional violation of the separation of powers. A court that can be reconstituted every time the executive and legislative bodies change hands isn't independent.

title: Biden Campaign Launches Door-Knocking Campaign
summary: Democratic volunteers start in-person canvassing after months of virtual organizing amid coronavirus concerns. Joe Biden's presidential campaign will begin door-knocking this week, a reversal after some Democratic groups in battleground states expressed concerns that its caution about social distancing was closing off a vital tool for reaching voters.

title: Long Before Nikola Trucks, Trevor Milton Sold Investors on Startups That Faded
summary: The entrepreneur's infectious vision drove his electric-vehicle company's value above Ford's before it crashed with his ouster. A look at his past ventures shows a pattern.. In 2009, Trevor Milton drove a Dodge pickup from Utah to Phoenix to show off his latest business idea: a truck using natural gas along with diesel to lower fuel costs.

title: Wireless Venture Ligado Seeks to Raise $4 Billion to Avoid Bankruptcy
summary: The wireless venture is preparing to launch a bond offering as soon as Monday to address debt maturities and buy time as it vies to get 5G-network project off the ground. Ligado Networks LLC is heading back to the debt markets in hopes of raising as much as $4 billion that would steer the wireless company clear of a possible bankruptcy, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Why Didn't Biden Condemn Antifa and Bernie Sanders?
summary: Not since George McGovern has a Democrat presidential nominee been so welcoming of extremist allies.. In Tuesday night's presidential debate in Cleveland, former Vice President Joe Biden said that violence is never "appropriate" but he did not condemn people who have been perpetrating it in cities across America. Taking the opportunity to address directly the antifa movement, Mr. Biden simply described its lack of centralized structure.

title: House Passes Bill to Allow Lawmakers to Oust U.S. Olympic Movement Leaders
summary: Move comes in wake of scandals over the movement's handling of finances, abuse claims and athlete welfare. Federal lawmakers passed a sweeping bill on Thursday giving themselves the ability to oust leaders of the U.S. Olympic movement, in the wake of scandals over the movement's handling of finances, abuse claims and athlete welfare.

title: U.S. Probes of Chinese Researchers Draw More Organized Opposition
summary: Kansas case presents test of Justice Department strategy and limits of government scrutiny. The Justice Department's effort to prosecute some Chinese researchers in the U.S. accused of hiding their ties to the Chinese government is facing increasing pushback from some academics and Chinese-American groups.

title: U.S. Army Saw Rise in Suicides as Covid-19 Pandemic Locked Down Nation
summary: Military leaders say stress of isolation from co-workers and family contributed to increase in deaths. WASHINGTON-Suicides among U.S. soldiers climbed since March as pandemic lockdowns began nationwide, raising questions within the Pentagon about how much isolation and other factors related to the coronavirus outbreak are driving the rise in deaths.

title: Long Island Diocese Files for Bankruptcy Amid Sex-Abuse Lawsuits
summary: A New York law lifting the statute of limitations for sex-abuse victims spurred litigation against the Diocese of Rockville Centre. The seat of the Roman Catholic Church in New York's Long Island filed for bankruptcy, becoming the largest diocese in the U.S. to seek chapter 11 protection over allegations of abuse by clergy.

title: Athene, MassMutual Made Over $3 Billion Takeover Offer to American Equity
summary: Transaction would be latest consolidation in the insurance industry. A pair of insurance companies made a bid for American Equity Investment Life Holding Co. last month, in a bet that the small Iowa insurer's retirement-income products will continue to be popular with conservative savers.

title: Oil's Recovery Set to Drag On Beyond Next Year
summary: Investment banks polled by WSJ expect an uneven recovery. Oil prices won't recover to pre-coronavirus levels by the end of next year, investment banks say.

title: Palantir, Asana Show Jury Still Out on Techs Going Direct
summary: Software companies see first-day gains but garner lower multiples than recent software IPOs. The test market for tech companies making direct stock listings has doubled overnight. The results are hardly conclusive.

title: Stocks Inch Higher to Start Quarter
summary: Investors assess whether Congress will pass another aid package to bolster economic growth ahead of the election. U.S. stocks edged slightly higher Thursday as investors tried to gauge the prospects of Washington passing an additional stimulus package to bolster the economy before next month's election.

title: U.S. Auto Sales Show Signs of Recovery in Third Quarter
summary: Cheap credit, demand for SUVs and pickup trucks drive faster-than-expected bounceback for car industry. The U.S. auto industry's recovery gathered momentum in the third quarter, with sales at auto makers rebounding from coronavirus-related lows and buyers returning to showrooms.

title: Can Trump Release His Tax Returns, and What Has the President Said?
summary: The president has long said he would release his tax returns, once an audit is complete. President Trump's tax returns are once again in the national spotlight, after a New York Times report that he paid $750 in federal income taxes in 2016 and 2017 and no taxes for many other recent years. That result stemmed from money-losing businesses, various tax credits and questionable deductions, according to the Times.

title: All Remdesivir Supplies to Be Distributed in U.S. by Maker Gilead
summary: Company will sell the Covid-19 drug directly to hospitals starting Thursday after U.S. government relinquishes control over supplies. The U.S. government is relinquishing control over supplies of remdesivir, the Covid-19 drug made by Gilead Sciences Inc. that had been in shortage since it was authorized for emergency use in May.

title: Vaccine's Development Won't Be Swayed by Politics, Pfizer CEO Says
summary: Albert Bourla sent an all-hands letter saying company won't bow to political pressure. Pfizer Inc.'s chief executive sought to assure the drugmaker's employees Thursday that their experimental Covid-19 vaccine wouldn't be influenced by politics, two days after President Trump mentioned the company during the debate.

title: The Best CBD Brands to Try, From Gummies to Olive Oils
summary: Want to give CBD a shot but skip the cloying neon-colored edibles? These infused chocolates, condiments, Turkish delights and more are designed for the discerning.. BY NOW we're used to seeing CBD at the drugstore, in tinctures, capsules, creams and balms. But a growing number of products promise to excite the palate even as they (purportedly) calm the nerves.

title: Rate of Crash Deaths on U.S. Roads Rose During Pandemic
summary: In first half of 2020, traffic volumes fell but speeding and other risky behaviors were up. The rate of crash deaths in the U.S. rose as the coronavirus pandemic erupted this spring, fueled by an increase in risky behaviors like speeding and by a reduced police presence on roadways, according to federal highway safety officials.

title: Mortgage Lender Caliber Home Loans Prepares for an IPO
summary: Deal could value the company at more than $2 billion. Caliber Home Loans Inc. is preparing for an initial public offering that could value the company, one of the largest U.S. mortgage lenders, at more than $2 billion.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended September 26
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Israel, Lebanon to Hold Talks to Resolve Maritime Border Dispute
summary: An agreement between the two countries, who are still formally at war, would allow them to tap offshore natural-gas reserves. Israel and Lebanon agreed to begin U.S.-brokered talks this month aimed at resolving a long-running maritime border dispute, an achievement that would allow both sides to exploit natural-gas reserves in the disputed area off their eastern Mediterranean coasts.

title: 2020 Is Proving How Much MSNBC's Ratings Hinge on Politics
summary: Cable channel fell behind rivals in the key demo when coronavirus and racial justice took center stage; new NBCUniversal News Group chairman isn't satisfied with third place. CNN and Fox News enjoyed a ratings boom this spring when there was a tsunami of news, between the escalating Covid-19 crisis and nationwide protests over police brutality.

title: The Secret to Setting the Right Price
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions about selling items online, the risks of tunnel vision and dealing with grief.. Dear Dan,

title: Rob Lowe Gets $45.5 Million for Montecito Home
summary: The '9-1-1: Lone Star' actor first listed the 10,000-square-foot California estate for $47 million back in 2018. Actor Rob Lowe and his wife, jewelry designer Sheryl Lowe, have struck a deal to sell their East Coast-style estate in the affluent enclave of Montecito, Calif., for around $45.5 million, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: BitMEX Co-Founders Charged With U.S. Rules Violations
summary: Regulators' anti-money-laundering lawsuit also targets popular exchange over cryptocurrency derivatives. The co-founders of one of the world's largest exchanges for trading cryptocurrency derivatives have been charged with violating U.S. anti-money-laundering rules as American authorities ramp up enforcement in one of the world's least regulated markets.

title: A $2 Billion Ski Development Creates an Avalanche of Controversy
summary: Resume Subscription. One of New York City's most prominent real-estate developers is betting years of his life-and a nine-figure sum-that he will be the first in four decades to successfully build a new, full-service ski resort in the United States.

title: U.S. Consumer Spending Rose in August, but Incomes Pose Hurdle for Recovery
summary: Commerce Department report shows personal income fell 2.7% due to a drop in unemployment benefits. A drop in household income and persistently high layoffs are threatening to further slow the U.S. economic recovery, which already appears to be losing momentum as the pandemic continues.

title: Deer Valley May Get a New Neighbor
summary: Abutting one of the country's most expensive ski resorts is an ambitious, expensive effort to turn 6,800 acres into Mayflower Mountain Resort.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.K. Regulator Wants Pension Funds, Other Organizations to Provide Better Disclosures
summary: The Financial Reporting Council found that some financial reports didn't meet its expectations. U.K. pension funds, insurance firms and asset managers need to better explain the purpose and governance structure of their organization, a regulator found.

title: General Motors' Credit Card, Brought to You by Goldman Sachs
summary: GM will be Goldman's second co-branded credit card after Apple card launch. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is buying General Motors Co. 's credit-card business for about $2.5 billion, a deal that furthers the Wall Street giant's push into Main Street lending.

title: PepsiCo Sales Snap Back From Pandemic
summary: Soda giant explores potential move into alcoholic drinks. People are grabbing a soda at the convenience store again.

title: Trump Administration Sets Cap on Refugees at 15,000, Another Record Low
summary: State Department says it expects more than 290,000 asylum claims from people already in the U.S. this fiscal year. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration plans to take in no more than 15,000 new refugees during the current fiscal year that began Oct. 1, the State Department said, bringing the limit to another record low.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond's Sales Bolstered by Digital, Back-to-College Growth
summary: Shares surge as the retailer reports an 89% increase in online sales, helped by consumers shopping for the home while being stuck inside. It was a summer of shopping for the home, from the home.

title: How Will Covid Impact This Year's Ski Season? More Face Masks and Less Après Ski
summary: Skiing at your favorite resort might look a little different this year. Here's what you need to know. Skiing might seem like the ideal pandemic activity: It is naturally socially distanced, occurring in the fresh air across swaths of open terrain. Wearing masks, gloves and goggles is already a norm.

title: Russian Online Retailer Ozon Group Prepares American IPO
summary: Offering could value company at $3 billion to $5 billion, as the coronavirus boosts e-commerce platforms by spurring more people to shop online. Ozon Group, one of Russia's biggest online retailers, is preparing for an initial public offering of stock in the U.S. later this year or beginning of next, according to people familiar with the company's plans, as the pandemic has boosted e-commerce platforms by spurring more people to shop online.

title: Fall Reading: Our Reviewers' Picks
summary: Marilynne Robinson, Elena Ferrante, and more reasons to love a bountiful season.. Fall is a cornucopia for readers, the moment when books that have been looked-for all through the year finally arrive in a kind of harvest-season profusion. This year, a delay in the publication of many eagerly awaited books originally slated to appear in spring means a bumper crop. But how to choose from such abundance? We can help: Here are 10 books-five new works of fiction, and five new biographies of fascinating figures-likely to be talked about through the season and beyond. Pick your own and settle in: Ripeness is all.

title: Innovation Relies on Imitation
summary: A new study of computer coders shows that the best problem-solvers learn from the efforts of their peers. Where do good ideas come from? How can we find new solutions to difficult, urgent problems, from the pandemic to the climate crisis? A zillion consulting firms and business books may claim that they know the answer, but there's been remarkably little empirical data.

title: Home Sales Surge in Resort Towns Even as Covid Looms Over Ski Season
summary: Resume Subscription. Rob Turner is a big skier. But it wasn't skiing that pushed him to make an all-cash, $1.3 million offer on a three-bedroom, four-bathroom, penthouse condo with ski-run views in Park City, Utah, in August.

title: Can Books Compete With Netflix? Yes, and Here's Why
summary: The latest Covid-19 trend is binge-reading. Independent bookstores are happy to oblige with special offers, free delivery and more.. IN A NORMAL year, Dayna Reber, a business analyst for a technology consulting firm in Camp Hill, Penn., would finish reading around three books. Thanks to the way Covid-19 has upended her daily routine, however, Ms. Reber, 30-who now works from home and rarely socializes offline-has polished off 46 volumes so far in 2020. And that count doesn't include the bedtime stories she reads to her 4-year-old.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond's Rebound Looks Too Springy
summary: Any hint of improvement at the retailer was likely to move the needle dramatically. Judging by Bed Bath & Beyond 's 30% share-price gain Thursday morning, one might assume the retailer reported some astronomical earnings.

title: Biden and Trump Are Both Right on Antifa
summary: It's an idea, not a group, and its radical leftist adherents refuse to disavow violence.. What is antifa? "An idea, not an organization," Joe Biden said during Tuesday's debate. "When a bat hits you over the head, that's not an idea," President Trump countered. "Antifa is a dangerous, radical group." Both men are right-Mr. Biden that antifa is foremost an ideology, and Mr. Trump about its propensity for violence.

title: On The Mountain in Park City
summary: Robert Turner paid $1.3 million for the property with ski-run views.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Tucked Away' in Aspen
summary: A Southampton contractor bought this three-acre property seven miles from the center of town for $2 million. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: People of Praise Deserves Ours
summary: America has a lot to learn from Amy Coney Barrett's 'covenant community.'. Most Americans had never heard of People of Praise before President Trump nominated Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court. Thanks to the media and the Democratic Party, many have been led to believe this community of faith-filled people is somehow sinister. It isn't.

title: From Oakland to the Wyoming Wilderness
summary: Carter Westfall and Kate West bought this $1.7 million home near the Jackson Hole ski area to live somewhere less populated.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Sizing Up Snowmass
summary: This 3,298-square-foot Colorado home on the Roaring Fork River is surrounded by 75-foot evergreen trees.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Incomes Starting to Buckle as Federal Support Fades
summary: While many households continue to have a financial cushion, those more affected by the pandemic are slipping further behind as stimulus talks bog down. The boost that government support was providing to the balance sheets of many Americans has demonstrably begun to fade. Unless something changes quickly, that will pose a major challenge to the economy's ability to recover.

title: U.S. Manufacturing Shows Improvement but Hiring Lags
summary: ISM, IHS Markit report solid demand at home and from abroad in September. U.S. manufacturing activity continues to rebound from the sharp downturn last spring, when factories closed to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

title: 'Here We Are' Review: Vanishing Act
summary: On Brighton Pier, at the end of the 1950s, three performers face a world on the brink of transformation.. Over the course of a 40-year career, the British author Graham Swift has perfected a distinctive style. His novels tend to be slim and lightly wrought; one might be tempted to call them slight were they not so rich in association, memory and reverberation. Rather in the manner of James Joyce or Virginia Woolf, Mr. Swift composes his fiction like a musical composition, with dominant themes, leitmotifs and meaningful refrains. Like them, too, he is intently concerned with history: the forward and backward movement of individual lives in time, played out against the backdrop of seismic social change.

title: 'The Man Who Ate Too Much' Review: American Appetite
summary: A Falstaffian biography captures the flavorful life of the figure who transformed the national palate.. Does anyone read James Beard anymore? Do home cooks still crack open one of his many voluminous recipe collections in search of how to prepare a roast chicken or design a dinner-party menu? Beard's contemporaries-Julia Child, M.F.K. Fisher, Edna Lewis-we still delight in, reading their prose, cooking their food and suffering through that blasted recipe for beef bourguignon. But the man once dubbed the dean of American cookery, the culinary personality whose name graces the "Oscars of the food world"-his books survive as fussy old-fashioned mementoes of a gastronomic era gone by. Why do we need James Beard?

title: 'Eleanor' Review: First Lady of the World
summary: How the awkward child of a wealthy clan became a defender of the downtrodden.. Looking back over the life of a phenomenal figure like Eleanor Roosevelt-crowded as it was with political achievement, activism and controversy-offers a strange contrast to her early life in the cloistered environs of 19th-century New York society. Emerging from this Whartonesque world of privilege, she transformed herself into one of the movers and shakers of her era. As a public figure, she loomed larger than many elected officials: She wrote a daily newspaper column, published more than 20 books, hosted radio and television programs. In one stunning volume, biographer David Michaelis-whose mother produced Eleanor Roosevelt's last television broadcast-gives us a sympathetic view of a complicated woman who changed and grew with every challenge.

title: Americans Will Treat Themselves This Halloween
summary: Candy is still selling, but the trick is to keep the good stuff for yourself. Amid the coronavirus pandemic, the annual custom of showing up at strangers' homes to demand candy will hold less appeal than usual come Halloween. But that won't stop Americans from consuming candy with abandon. As with everything else these days, the key is just to do so alone at home.

title: How to Create a Chic Home Office Out of Random Furniture
summary: As coronavirus upended our home lives, many people found themselves trying to make a WFH space out of disparate ingredients. Designers suggest décor to pull two odd elements together.. WHEN THE pandemic struck and forced so many Americans to shun office buildings and embrace the idea of WFH, many of us floundered. Our apartments and bungalows lacked home offices. Kitchen islands were drafted as muffin-crumb-strewn "desks." Some of us retreated to our beds to curl up with a laptop in ways psychologists might have found troubling.

title: PepsiCo, Conagra Still Riding Pandemic Food Wave
summary: Food companies keep benefiting as Americans are using their kitchens more than ever. But health considerations still matter to sales.. The eat-at-home trend isn't going anywhere, to the lasting benefit of American food companies.

title: The U.S. Economy Was Laden With Debt Before Covid. That's Bad News for a Recovery.
summary: The country entered the new recession with record levels of debt. Fourteen charts show how we got there-and what it means.. The coronavirus brought an end to the longest economic expansion in U.S. history. That wasn't the only problem. When the U.S. barreled into the deep downturn that followed, it was laden with debt.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Journey From Oppression to Independence
summary: In a newly translated memoir, the Russian novelist and dissident describes how he found a tranquil refuge in Vermont.. The Russian novelist Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn (1918-2008), one of the great writers of the 20th century, helped to inform the world about the evils of the Gulag, the Soviet prison-camp system, in books such as "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich" and "The Gulag Archipelago." Awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1970, he was forced to leave the Soviet Union four years later, and in 1976 he settled with his family in Cavendish, Vt., where he lived for the next 18 years.

title: U.S. to Start Forgiving PPP Loans After Borrowers Complained
summary: Small Business Administration aims to begin approving requests late this week or early next, following concerns forgiveness process under $670 billion program was too complex. WASHINGTON-The Small Business Administration will begin forgiving loans granted to small-business owners under the Paycheck Protection Program, the Treasury Department said Tuesday, following banks' and borrowers' complaints that the process had been bogged down.

title: Global Maritime Regulator Hit by Cyberattack
summary: International Maritime Organization is the second shipping entity attacked by hackers in the past week. The International Maritime Organization, the United Nations arm that regulates global shipping, said its London headquarters has been hit by a cyberattack that brought down its website and internal web-based services.

title: Senate Panel Authorizes Subpoenas for Top Social-Media CEOs
summary: Google's Sundar Pichai, Twitter's Jack Dorsey and Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg are in line to be called to testify on their companies' legal immunity provisions. WASHINGTON-The Senate Commerce Committee voted to authorize subpoenas forcing testimony from Facebook Inc. CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Twitter Inc . CEO Jack Dorsey, and Sundar Pichai, CEO of Alphabet Inc . and its subsidiary Google, setting up what could be a contentious hearing with the largest U.S. social-media companies in the midst of a national election.

title: Stretching Breaks Can Be Hazardous to Your Health-and Dignity
summary: Home-office workers seek relief for sedentary muscles but find risks. Stacey Sullivan is no gymnast. But at 6 a.m. in her dark home office, she ended up in the splits.

title: Alexei Navalny Accuses Putin of Ordering Novichok Attack
summary: Prominent opposition figure vows to return to Russia to challenge the leadership. MOSCOW-Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny blamed President Vladimir Putin for his poisoning with a Soviet-era nerve agent and promised to return to Moscow to fight for political change in Russia.

title: Jobless Claims Hold Steady for Fifth Straight Week
summary: Applications for unemployment benefits remained above 800,000, reflecting a slowing jobs recovery. New applications for unemployment benefits in the U.S. fell slightly last week but remained between 800,000 and 900,000 for the fifth straight week, reflecting a labor-market recovery that is losing momentum.

title: Vatican Officials Cut Budget Deficit Prior to Pandemic
summary: Holy See's budget gap for 2019 falls significantly, but bigger losses loom for 2020. ROME-The Holy See cut its budget deficit for 2019, reducing the financial pressures from previous investment losses, but the pandemic and its economic fallout pose new challenges for the headquarters of the Catholic Church.

title: Soaring Biomedical IPOs Raise Questions About Money Left on the Table
summary: Debate emerges over how aggressively to price life-sciences IPOs. Soaring initial public offerings for many biomedical startups are injecting cash into these companies as they seek cures for Covid-19, cancer and other diseases.

title: Titans Game Postponed Indefinitely as Team's Covid-19 Case Count Rises
summary: Two additional members of the organization received positive test results, bringing the team's total count to 11 and raising questions about the rocky path forward in the NFL's pandemic season. The Tennessee Titans' Week 4 game against the Pittsburgh Steelers has been postponed indefinitely amid a growing Covid-19 outbreak inside the team.

title: The Tool That Transformed Wine Tasting
summary: In 1984, a professor at the University of California, Davis, introduced her Wine Aroma Wheel. Its goal: to banish pretension and get more precision from the language we use to describe what we're drinking.. WHEN I PUT my nose into a glass of wine, I can usually and reasonably cogently describe what I smell. But if I used a Wine Aroma Wheel, would I detect even more?

title: Venezuela's Food Chain Is Breaking, and Millions Go Hungry
summary: A report found 13% of children under 5 are stunted; oil-rich nation is 'on the edge of an irreversible catastrophe'. Ana Nuñez, a 62-year-old retired municipal worker in western Venezuela, says her meals often consist of just a few corn-flour pancakes, known as arepas.

title: Russia's Top Arms Expert: Moscow Won't 'Be Drawn Into an Expensive Arms Race'
summary: Excerpts from the WSJ interview with Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov. The Wall Street Journal interviewed Russia's top arms-control negotiator, Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov, on the prospects for a future nuclear agreement. Here are some of the questions and responses, edited for space.

title: The Imperial Overreach of China's Belt and Road Initiative
summary: Xi Jinping's signature foreign project is poorly defined, badly mismanaged and visibly failing. Pundits often describe today's China as uber-strategic, seeing its every move as carefully coordinated, guided by history and focused on the long run. But Chinese leader Xi Jinping's signature foreign-policy vision, the Belt and Road Initiative, is actually poorly defined and horribly mismanaged. As China pushes ahead with this colossal infrastructure-building spree, it is following in the footsteps of past empires and seriously overreaching.

title: Ford CFO Tim Stone to Leave Company
summary: His exit after 18 months is the latest high-profile Detroit auto executive defection to the technology industry. Tim Stone, Ford Motor Co.'s chief financial officer, is leaving the auto maker after 18 months to join a software firm, the latest high-profile Detroit auto executive to defect to the technology industry.

title: Brett Icahn to Rejoin His Father's Firm
summary: Carl Icahn's son to lead new investment team and join Icahn Enterprises Board. Carl Icahn is finally ready to loosen the reins on his investment empire.

title: Russia Rebuffs Trump's Arms-Control Proposal
summary: Moscow dismisses U.S. pressure for an election-year deal to extend the old nuclear arms-control treaty while negotiating a broader, new one. Russia's top arms-control negotiator has rejected the Trump administration's core requirements for a new nuclear arms-control treaty, dealing a blow to the White House's hopes of concluding an election-year framework agreement with Moscow.

title: Tesla Stock, Bed Bath, Boeing, PepsiCo: What to Watch When the Market Opens Today
summary: Stocks are poised to start the fourth quarter on an upbeat note, with S&P 500 futures pointing to gains after the market open. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Thursday.

title: What's Going On With Baseball's Wacky Playoffs? Let Me Try to Explain
summary: MLB follows a brisk regular season with a deliciously chaotic wild-card round. Major League Baseball's playoffs are under way, and don't worry if you're confused and need catching up. I'm confused and need catching up! This has already been a very strange year for baseball-each team started with a brisk 60-game schedule, down from the usual 85,000-game slog. Creepy cardboard cutouts sat lifelessly in the bleachers. Entire clubs confronted quarantine. Games started extra innings with a runner on second base. Luke Voit (22 dingers) is your home run champion. The San Diego Padres felt like America's Team. It's very uncharacteristic and goes against everything baseball has traditionally stood for. I've enjoyed it very much.

title: Trump Tax-Return Report Fuels Democrats' Drive to Tax the Rich
summary: Bolstering IRS enforcement could also yield more revenue, some argue. President Trump's apparently minuscule tax payments are pumping new energy into Democrats' plans to raise taxes on rich people and beef up the Internal Revenue Service.

title: K-Ming Chang's 'Bestiary': A Debut Novel in Which Mythology Is Real and a Girl Turns Into a Tiger
summary: An intergenerational tale about three Taiwanese-American women, 'Bestiary' blurs the lines between humans and animals, exploring the stories we tell about ourselves to survive.. When author K-Ming Chang was in sixth grade, she wrote a story inspired by the Chinese myths she had heard as a child. The main character in her story had the ability to turn into a tiger. "It was really terrible," she recalls, laughing. She revisited the story recently and realized that now, some elements of it are in her debut novel, Bestiary, out September 29 from One World. In it, the book's protagonist, called Daughter, starts turning into a tiger after her mother tells her the folktale of Hu Gu Po, a tiger spirit who eats children in the hopes of becoming a human. Daughter grows a tail that yields her a power she doesn't know how to use and access to her magical ancestral history.

title: How Garrett Bradley's Films Reset Our Personal Algorithms
summary: With 'Time,' a Sundance-winning documentary debuting this month on Amazon Prime, and a major museum show opening, artist and filmmaker Garrett Bradley is gaining recognition for her resonant work. For Garrett Bradley, an artist and filmmaker whose work examines memory, history, time and Blackness, a bag of videotapes she received about two years ago turned out to be a transformative gift. In early 2018, Bradley was finishing filming a documentary short about a New Orleans woman's fight to get her husband released from a 60-year prison sentence. As Bradley parted ways with Sibil Fox Richardson, the film's main protagonist, Fox Richardson casually handed Bradley a bag. "It was like, 'Oh, maybe this will be useful to you,' " Bradley, 34, recalls. Inside it were two decades of video diaries that Fox Richardson, who goes by Fox Rich, had recorded for her incarcerated husband, Rob: intimate evidence of her life raising their six sons, bearing witness to the everyday moments he'd missed.

title: Is Decoupling from China Worth $1 Trillion?
summary: Resume Subscription. How do companies move supply chains outside China when it is the only big economy experiencing meaningful growth? Without major government help, they may not.

title: As Covid-19 Spreads Among Youth, Europe's Governments Move to End the Party
summary: Resume Subscription. Younger people are driving the current surge in Covid-19 cases across Europe, forcing governments to re-engineer pandemic-fighting plans forged in the spring when different demographics prevailed.

title: As Pandemic Boosts Home Demand, Startup Sells a New Ownership Model
summary: Pacaso is using a vacation model to sell ownership in weekend homes. Americans feeling trapped at home during the pandemic want more space. The creators of a new startup think they can deliver it with a fresh spin on the timeshare business.

title: U.S. Banks Are Pulling More Assets From London
summary: London's position as a gateway to Europe for U.S. banks is being eroded. London's standing as the one-stop shop for American banks doing business in Europe is slipping, as lenders speed up movement of people and assets from the U.K. to the continent before a Brexit transition period ends Dec. 31.

title: H&M Heads Into Winter With a Sharper New Look
summary: After years of underperformance, the Swedish fast fashion chain is using the crisis to slash rents, close stores and speed up its digital makeover. Global fashion retailers face a potentially harsh winter, but at least they aren't wasting the crisis.

title: West Coast Wildfires Devastate Heart of California's Wine Industry
summary: Resume Subscription. For the first time in its 46-year history, Alexander Eisele's Napa Valley vineyard won't turn the grapes it grows into wine this fall.

title: Kim Jong Un's New Look Is More Man Than Superhuman
summary: Resume Subscription. SEOUL-For decades, North Korea's ruling Kims portrayed themselves as quasi-gods, incapable of error.

title: Debate Showed Trump Hasn't Settled on Main Message Against Biden
summary: Unlike in 2016, the president has lobbed a variety of attacks against his opponent rather than focusing on one argument. CLEVELAND-President Trump has spent six months searching for a clear message that would erode his challenger's lead in the polls. With less than five weeks left in the race, the incumbent still hasn't found an answer.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Trials Need Only a Fraction of People to Get Sick
summary: Late-stage trials evaluating safety, efficacy of coronavirus vaccines are waiting for 150-160 cases to crop up. Late-stage trials for Covid-19 vaccines are signing up tens of thousands of volunteers, but only a tiny fraction will help decide whether the shots work safely enough to be given widely.

title: Expedia Isn't Ready for an Extended Stay
summary: Its homestay business may be booming, but it isn't the key to the online travel agent's recovery. Investors bidding up Expedia Group might be mistaking it for Airbnb.

title: Playboy to Go Public Again in Deal With SPAC
summary: The company, which pivoted to brand licensing and commerce, is valued at $415 million. Playboy is going public again after being acquired by a blank-check firm, a deal that valued the brand made famous by its iconic adult magazine at $415 million, the company said Thursday.

title: Hong Kong's Leader Says Stability Has Been Restored, With City Under Heavy Police Presence
summary: Opposition camp calls for people to protest after police rejected an application for organized rally. HONG KONG-Chief Executive Carrie Lam said stability had been restored in Hong Kong three months after Beijing imposed national-security legislation, as thousands of police officers fanned out to pre-empt any protests that might disrupt Thursday's celebration of China's National Day.

title: Investors Have a Local Route into China's Hydrogen Plans
summary: Beijing has committed an extra $2.5 billion to hydrogen power, a boon to Chinese engine maker Weichai and its Western partners Ballard and Ceres. China is further along the road to adopting hydrogen as a potentially green transport fuel than most of its peers. Investors don't need to buy Chinese stocks to gain exposure.

title: How the Minnesota Twins Became the Worst Playoff Team in Sports History
summary: After getting swept by the Astros, the Twins have now lost 18 consecutive postseason contests. The last time the Minnesota Twins won a playoff game, Joe Mauer was a rookie and the franchise still called the Metrodome home. It was Oct. 5, 2004, when the Boston Red Sox were cursed by the Babe, "Steve Bartman" was a topical reference on Chicago's North Side and the Washington Nationals were the Montreal Expos.

title: Former Airbnb Marketing Chief Jonathan Mildenhall Joins Banking Startup Dave
summary: Mr. Mildenhall will have a nine-figure marketing budget to boost Dave's profile and customer base in a crowded challenger bank category. Jonathan Mildenhall, who has held senior marketing roles at Coca-Cola Co. and Airbnb Inc., will lead marketing for less well-known banking upstart Dave Inc., with the goal of building its brand and bringing more people into banking, he said.

title: Demand for Big-Box Warehouses Soars Under E-Commerce Surge, Report Says
summary: Amazon is leading a pack of companies rushing to fill the biggest industrial sites in the U.S., says real-estate brokerage firm Colliers. A key measure of demand for big warehouses soared 51% in the first half of 2020 as the pandemic-driven surge in online sales sent companies scrambling for space to store and deliver goods to locked-down consumers.

title: Google Pledges $1 Billion in Licensing Payments to News Publishers
summary: Der Spiegel, Stern and others to supply article previews for tech firm's Google News Showcase. Alphabet Inc.'s Google said Thursday it would pay publishers more than $1 billion over the next three years to license news content for a new product called Google News Showcase.

title: Why 2020 Should Be the Year of the Man-Heel
summary: Men's heels might seem a provocative choice best left to bombastic rock stars, but thanks to brands such as Celine and Saint Laurent, shoes and boots with subtle lifts are on the rise-and they're a lot more wearable (and historically masculine) than most guys think. DENNIS GREENBAUM has a thing for heeled boots. He's not a brazen rock star like Harry Styles or Rick James, careening across stages and strutting down red carpets in elevated shoes. He's a retired 68-year-old in Maryland who used to work in ad sales and simply likes a lift. The attraction began with 1.5-inch-heel cowboy boots and evolved into a fondness for 2.5-inch Johnny Boots designed by Tom Ford for Yves Saint Laurent in the early 2000s. He contends they're the most comfortable shoes he owns. "I have never been self-conscious about my height," said Mr. Greenbaum, who stands at 5'7". "But when I wear the heel, it's impossible for me to slouch. You have to stand straight." He especially enjoys that heels lend him a leaner shape-particularly when paired with high-waisted pants. "They elongate my whole body, which makes a difference in how I look in photos."

title: California Firefighters Tap AI for Edge in Battling Wildfires
summary: Stretched by longer, deadlier fire seasons, officials are using artificial intelligence to more closely track blazes and more judiciously steer resources. Agencies battling wildfires in California are turning to artificial intelligence and other technologies to predict the spread of blazes and help guide the response of firefighting crews.

title: Secretive High-Speed Trading Firm Hits Jackpot With TikTok
summary: Susquehanna International Group is sitting on stake in app's owner estimated at more than $15 billion. No matter the outcome of the struggle between China and the U.S. over video-sharing app TikTok, an unlikely winner will be a secretive trading firm based outside of Philadelphia.

title: Asphalt Company Got $70 Million Break on Penalty
summary: Sargeant Marine's criminal penalty could have been $90 million, but was shorn to $16.6 million under the Justice Department's latest guidance on inability-to-pay claims. Facing a bribery probe, asphalt company Sargeant Marine Inc. claimed that a large criminal penalty would make it insolvent. So federal prosecutors knocked off more than $70 million.

title: South Korea's Market Rebound Heats Up Argument Over Bringing Back Short Selling
summary: The country is keeping in place for a year a ban on the practice introduced in March, when markets convulsed. Surging stocks. A foreign buyers' strike. Death threats.

title: The Lakers Get Hot and Beat the Heat in the NBA Finals
summary: They're not a good 3-point shooting team. But the Lakers won Game 1 because they couldn't miss.. The first game of the NBA Finals this year was always going to be weird. But what happened on Wednesday night was deeply weird even by the standards of this year: The Los Angeles Lakers briefly turned into the best shooting team on the planet.

title: ECB Steps Up Support for Credit Markets
summary: Central bank more than tripled its corporate-bond buying last week, compared with the same week in August. The European Central Bank is ramping up its corporate-bond purchases, increasing its support for the region's companies as weaker economic data weigh on credit markets.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange Trading Is Halted by System Problem
summary: Shutdown blocks all trades for full day, in worst case since current system started in 1999. The Tokyo Stock Exchange halted all stock trading for Thursday's session due to a system problem, a rare glitch that market participants said could undermine trust in the exchange.

title: President Trump Signs Spending Bill After Brief Lapse in Funding
summary: The short-term measure keeps the government funded through Dec. 11. WASHINGTON-President Trump ended a brief lapse in the federal government's funding early Thursday morning when he signed a short-term spending bill within an hour after the midnight deadline.

title: Augmented Reality Offers a Promise of Incision-Free Autopsies
summary: To advance forensic medicine, scientists are banking on technologies, from 3-D body simulations to algorithmic image scanning. Author

title: California Rolls Out Diversity Quotas for Corporate Boards
summary: State's new requirements for racial and other minority representation follow gender mandate. California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation Wednesday that will require the boards of publicly traded companies based in the state to have at least one racially, ethnically or otherwise diverse director by 2021.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Commission Considers Changes to Format After Raucous First Debate
summary: Trump's answer on white supremacists reverberates, draws criticism from members of both parties. Chaos at Tuesday's fiery presidential debate prompted organizers to promise to change the structure of the remaining matchups between President Trump and Democrat Joe Biden, as members of both parties criticized the president on Wednesday for his deflections when asked to condemn white-supremacist groups.

title: American Airlines, United to Cut 32,000 Jobs as Washington Debates Relief
summary: American says it will bring workers back if lawmakers approve an extension of aid to airlines. American Airlines Group Inc. and United Airlines Holdings Inc. will go forward for now with a total of more than 32,000 job cuts Thursday after lawmakers were unable to agree on a broad coronavirus-relief package, the airlines told employees.

title: CDC Extends Cruising Ban to Oct. 31
summary: Agency had drafted plan to extend no-sail order to February, but White House opts for shorter ban instead. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention extended its ban on cruise sailings in the U.S. by a month, to Oct. 31, matching the industry's plans to restart a business that has been largely suspended by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Trump Campaign Adviser Brad Parscale Stepping Away From the Race
summary: The decision comes after a standoff with police in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.. WASHINGTON-Brad Parscale is stepping away from the Trump campaign following a standoff with police that culminated in his hospitalization for psychiatric evaluation, a campaign official said Wednesday.

title: House Delays Vote on $2.2 Trillion Coronavirus Bill Lacking GOP Backing
summary: Democratic aides say postponement is to allow two sides one more day to keep talking. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives postponed a vote on a $2.2 trillion coronavirus aid package as Democrats tried to find common ground with the White House on a bipartisan agreement, though they remained far apart on key issues.

title: Palantir Grabs $21 Billion Valuation, but Debut Comes With a Hiccup
summary: Technical issues prevented some existing investors from unloading shares for much of Wednesday afternoon. Palantir Technologies Inc. and Asana Inc. made history by both completing direct listings on the New York Stock Exchange on the same day, a milestone for the little-tested way to go public.

title: New Jersey Veterans Homes Likely Failed to Attribute Covid-19 as Cause in Dozens of Deaths
summary: Facilities in Menlo Park and Paramus suffered massive coronavirus outbreaks. A state-run nursing home for veterans in New Jersey failed to attribute nearly 40% of its likely Covid-19 deaths to the virus, according to the state's own Department of Health.

title: What Americans Thought of the First Presidential Debate
summary: Economic reopening separated men from women. Talk of law and order split voters by race. How the nation's divisions mirrored those on the debate stage.. Men approved of President Trump's calls to reopen businesses and schools, while women were more skeptical. Independent voters liked Mr. Trump's emphasis on putting Americans back to work but also former Vice President Joe Biden's promise to rescind the president's 2017 tax cuts.
